G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County under G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the incident giving rise to this action occurred in Suffolk County, Massachusetts.

(G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B).proposition: Plaintiff was riding lawfully, wearing a helmet, and adhering to all applicable traffic laws governing bicyclists under Massachusetts law (G.L. c. 85, § 11B).

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 90, § 14, a driver must exercise caution to avoid endangering bicyclists when opening doors adjacent to roadways.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Massachusetts law—common and statutory—establishes that Defendant’s actions constitute actionable negligence.

*Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachuse.proposition: Massachusetts law—common and statutory—establishes that Defendant’s actions constitute actionable negligence.
*Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachuse.support_reasoning: The case does not support the proposition that defendant’s actions constitute actionable negligence under Massachusetts law. Instead, the SJC holds that the evidence was insufficient, as a matter of law, to show that the defendant breached its duty of reasonable care or had actual or constructive notice of the icy condition, and therefore the defendant was entitled to judgment notwithstanding the verdict. The opinion thus affirms no actionable negligence on these facts and is authority in favor of the defense, not the plaintiff.
*Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachuse.relevant_excerpt: “After reviewing the evidence presented at the first trial, we conclude that the defendant’s motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict should have been allowed because the evidence, viewed in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, was not sufficient to warrant an inference that the defendant violated the duty of reasonable care that it owed to the plaintiff. … Specifically, we hold that the evidence did not warrant an inference that the defendant knew, or in the exercise of reasonable care should have known, of the icy condition that caused the plaintiff’s fall.”

*Leibovich v. Antonellis*, 410 Mass. 568.proposition: Massachusetts law—common and statutory—establishes that Defendant’s actions constitute actionable negligence.
*Leibovich v. Antonellis*, 410 Mass. 568.support_reasoning: The opinion assumes and reports that the jury found the defendant negligent, but the appeal does not concern whether his conduct met the elements of negligence under Massachusetts common or statutory law. Instead, the court addresses evidentiary rulings, jury instructions on taxes, and the retroactive application and constitutionality of the filial consortium statute. The case therefore does not establish or analyze a general rule that the defendant’s actions constitute actionable negligence; it simply leaves the negligence verdict undisturbed.
*Leibovich v. Antonellis*, 410 Mass. 568.relevant_excerpt: “A jury in the Superior Court concluded that the defendant had operated his truck in a negligent manner, causing serious personal injuries to the plaintiffs’ son. The jury returned verdicts in favor of the plaintiffs… The defendant appealed from the judgments assessing the damages… The defendant’s liability was premised on the jury’s finding that he had been traveling well above the posted speed limit… There was ample testimony at trial as to the defendant’s speed.”

*Moylan v. Dykes*, 181 Mass. 68 (1902).proposition: Defendant’s failure to exercise due care in this situation creates civil liability for the resulting injuries and damages inflicted on Plaintiff.
*Moylan v. Dykes*, 181 Mass. 68 (1902).case_name: Kelsey v. New York, New Haven, & Hartford Railroad
*Moylan v. Dykes*, 181 Mass. 68 (1902).support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that a defendant’s failure to exercise due care here creates civil liability; this case holds the opposite. The court concludes there was no sufficient evidence of negligence in sounding the whistle or in the condition of the bridge and upholds directed verdicts for the defendant. Thus, the opinion rejects, rather than affirms, liability on these facts and does not support the claimed proposition.
*Moylan v. Dykes*, 181 Mass. 68 (1902).relevant_excerpt: “We are of opinion that, under all the circumstances of this case, there was no sufficient evidence of negligence on the part of the defendant in blowing the whistle… As we have found that there was no sufficient evidence of negligence on the part of the defendant, in the first two cases, it follows that the plaintiffs in the last two cases… cannot maintain their actions for the death of their intestates.”

*Fiore v. Hernandez*, 59 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s failure to exercise due care in this situation creates civil liability for the resulting injuries and damages inflicted on Plaintiff.
*Fiore v. Hernandez*, 59 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion is a land use / public way status case about whether Old Poplar Hill Road remained a county highway for zoning frontage purposes. It does not involve negligence, due care, or civil liability for personal injuries or damages. The court’s reasoning is confined to statutory and historical interpretation of highway layout and discontinuance, so it does not establish any rule about failure to exercise due care creating civil liability.
*Fiore v. Hernandez*, 59 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "Recore and Kurkulonis commenced this action in the Land Court in June, 1998, seeking a declaration that a way shown on their proposed subdivision plan for certain land in Conway was a ‘county highway’ and, hence, could be used to satisfy the frontage requirement established by the town’s zoning by-law for a buildable lot. ... We, therefore, conclude that the judge did not err in determining that the order the commissioners entered in 1845 automatically discontinued the way shown on the plaintiffs’ plan as a county road."
